title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act titled "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" requires visa waiver participants to electronically submit biographical information. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The system must provide an eligibility determination within 30 minutes. The system for visa waiver program participants must electronically determine eligibility within 30 minutes. Carriers and corporations must electronically inquire about passengers' visa status before embarkation. The system for visa waiver program participants must electronically determine eligibility within 30 minutes. Carriers and corporations described in section 217(a)(5) of the Act must inquire electronically about alien passengers' visa status before embarkation. The system deployment should happen soon after the enactment of the Act, and a fee will be charged to aliens to ensure cost recovery. The system for visa waiver program participants must electronically determine eligibility within 30 minutes. Deployment should occur promptly after the Act's enactment, and a fee will be charged to aliens for cost recovery. Consultation with private sector experts is required during system development. SEC. 3. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas, travel documents, and passports issued to aliens by October 26, 2005. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, is required to install equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of passports issued by October 26, 2005. The deadline for implementing technology standards in the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act is extended to 2005. Additionally, a limited good faith waiver is introduced. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act extends the deadline for implementing technology standards to 2005 and introduces a limited good faith waiver allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act extends the deadline for implementing technology standards to 2005 and introduces a limited good faith waiver allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements. Factors considered include efforts made by countries to meet requirements by specific dates. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act extends the deadline for implementing technology standards to 2005 and introduces a limited good faith waiver allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall issue an initial report on the status of countries' progress in meeting the requirements by specific dates. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall issue an initial report by October 26, 2005, and a final report by April 25, 2006, on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security".
